abstract.text: An object that determines which audio to play.

legalNotices.copyright: Copyright © 2025 Apple Inc. All rights reserved.

inlineContent.text: A sound event represents a logic tree, or hierarchy, that defines what, when, and how the framework plays a sound at runtime. You configure the tree with conditions based on your app’s state. When you invoke a sound event’s root node at runtime, the framework navigates the tree by branching based on the logic, landing on a playable node that sends the right audio to the output device:
To invoke a specific one-time sound, create a sound event from a single sampler node.
To invoke a sound event that tailors its sound based on your app’s state, define a sound event hierarchy containing one or more control nodes; see
. For example, to play either footsteps or a jumping noise depending on the hero’s state, you configure a switch node that navigates based on the hero’s hypothetical
For sound event nodes that play audio, the asset’s
determines whether the audio loops. One-time sound events stop automatically at the end of the audio data. Looping sound events (those with

Apps create a sound event by requesting one from a sound event node asset. To create a sound event node asset, combine a sound asset (the source audio data) with a mixer object (which combines sound layers for output) to create a node, and add the node to the asset registry. By creating a sound event from a sampler node (
), the following code plays an audio file once before discarding it.

code: // Create a channel layout for audio types that contain no channel metadata.
// Load an audio file from the bundle.
// Create and register a sound asset.
} catch { print("Failed to register the sound asset.") }
// Create a mixer that routes sound directly to the output.
// Add the sound event node to the asset registry and retrieve the asset object.
} catch { print ("Failed to register the sound event node.") }

inlineContent.text: The resulting node asset represents a template for audio that’s ready for playback. To play the audio, spawn a sound event off of the node asset and call

code: // Create a playable sound event from the template sound event asset.
} catch { print ("Failed to create the sound event.") }

inlineContent.text: To play the same sound asset again, create another sound event object. After the first
instance, subsequent calls have no effect.

abstract.text: Create dynamic audio experiences in your game or app that react to events and cues in the environment.
A base class that adds a name to framework assets.
An option that restarts a sound from the begining after it finishes.
A node that plays complete audio data.
An option that determines whether the node’s audio plays in a loop.
A sound resource stored in the asset registry.
An object that determines which audio to play.
Indicates the results of sound-event preparation.
Indicates the state of sound-event preparation.
The playback status of audio.
Indicates the status after a sound event changes its playback position.
Indicates the status after starting a sound event.
Creates a sound event node with the given asset.
Creates a sound event node with the given asset and mixer parameters.
A Boolean value that indicates whether the sound loops or stops on its own.
The object’s meta parameters.
Nodes in the event tree that control the volume of their child nodes.
Pauses the sound event.
Enables a sound event to play and runs the argument code when the sound event plays back.
The status of sound-event preparation.
A collection of audio streams for playback.
The sound event’s playback status.
Resumes the sound event.
Advances the sound event’s playback position to a specific time.
Invokes the sound event and runs the specified code on completion.
Stops a sound event and prevents it from resuming.
A template object for sounds that can play in reaction to environmental state.
A base class for sound event nodes that connect to form a node hierarchy.
Position sound from a specific direction and automatically raise or lower volume based on the environment.

doc://com.apple.phase/documentation/PHAS.title: Playing sound from a location in a 3D scene

abstract.text: Objects that connect to form a hierarchical tree of audio actions.
The root class of most Objective-C class hierarchies, from which subclasses inherit a basic interface to the runtime system and the ability to behave as Objective-C objects.
The group of methods that are fundamental to all Objective-C objects.
A type that can be hashed into a `Hasher` to produce an integer hash value.
A type that can be compared for value equality.
A type with a customized textual representation.
A type with a customized textual representation suitable for debugging purposes.
A type whose instances can be encoded, and appropriately passed, as elements of a C `va_list`.
